tn.text: The phrase "went down" is used here because Timnah is lower in elevation than where his father's house was. Timah is the name of a city in the Sorek Valley. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: one of the daughters of the Philistines
tn.text: The word "daughter" is a polite way to refer to a young, unmarried woman. AT: "one of the unmarried women among the Philistine people" or "a Philistine girl" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: Now get her for me to be my wife
tn.text: This is an idiom. Samson was demanding his parents to speak to the Philistine woman's parents about marriage. AT: "Now arrange for her to become my wife!" or "Make the arrangements for me to marry her!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Is there not a woman among the daughters of your relatives, or among all our people?
tn.text: They ask this question to suggest that they could find Samson a wife among their own people. This question can be written as a statement. AT: "Surely there are women among your people whom you could marry." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The word "daughter" is a polite way to refer to a young, unmarried woman. AT: "one of the unmarried women among your relatives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: Are you going to take a wife from the uncircumcised Philistines?
tn.text: This question is asked to rebuke Samson. This question can be written as a statement. You can make explicit the reason his parents do not want him to marry a Philistine. AT: "You really should not marry a Philistine woman because the Philistine people do not worship Yahweh." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This is an idiom. Samson was demanding his parents to speak to the Philistine woman's parents about marriage. AT: "Now arrange for her to be my wife" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that Samson thinks she is beautiful. "I am pleased by how beautiful she is" or "she is beautiful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to Samson's request to marry the Philistine woman.

tn.ref: for he desired to create a conflict
tn.text: The word "he" refers to Yahweh.

The phrase "went down" is used here because Timnah is lower in elevation than where his father's house was. Timnah was a city in the Sorek Valley. Translate the name of this city the same way you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:14:01|14:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: And, look, there one of the young lions came up
tn.text: Here the word "look" is used to draw the readers attention to a surprising event that happens in the story. The phrase "came up" means that the lion came near him. AT: "Suddenly, a young lion came near him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"threatened him." This is the kind of noise that a lion makes when it threatens to attack something.

tn.ref: Yahweh's Spirit suddenly came on him
tn.text: The phrase "came on" means that Yahweh's Spirit influenced Samson. In this case, he made him very strong. AT: "Yahweh's Spirit made him very strong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
tore into two pieces
Here it states that he had nothing in his hand to emphasize that he was not holding a weapon. AT: "did not have a weapon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
This means that he thought she was very beautiful.  AT: "he was pleased by how beautiful she was" or "he thought she was very beautiful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This means that he left his path to do something. AT: "he left the path" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"dead body"

tn.ref: And, look, there was a swarm of bees
tn.text: Here the word "look" is used to draw the reader's attention to something surprising that happens in the story.  AT: "He found a swarm of bees" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
large group of insects
"gathered up"

tn.ref: Samson's father went down to where the woman was
tn.text: The phrase "went down" is used to describe Timnah which is lower in elevation than where Samson's father lives. AT: "Samson's father went to where the woman lived" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: the custom of the young men
tn.text: It may be helpful to state that this was a marriage custom. AT: "the custom of young men who were getting married" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"30 of their friends" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
a game in which the players must discover the answer to a difficult question
This means to figure out the meaning of the riddle. AT: "can figure out its meaning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: thirty linen robes and thirty sets of clothes
tn.text: "30 linen robes and 30 sets of clothes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: But if you cannot tell me
tn.text: Here the word "you" is plural and refers to the guests at the feast. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
a type of cloth
Samson tells his riddle. Since it is supposed to be hard to understand, do not translate it in a way that people will immediately know what it means.

tn.ref: Out of the eater was something to eat
tn.text: "Out of the eater came something to eat" or "Something to eat came out of something that eats"
The word "eater," an abstract noun can be expressed as a verb. AT: "the thing that eats" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: out of the strong was something sweet
tn.text: "out of the strong came something sweet" or "Something that is sweet came out of something that is strong"
This refers to something that is strong. AT: "the strong thing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"the men at his feast"

Here figuring out the answer to the riddle is spoke of as if it were something hidden that the guest had to search for and find. AT: "could not figure out the answer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"the 4th day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
mislead or fool someone into doing something they would not want to do

Possible meanings are 1) this refers to the actual house. AT: "the house your father and his family live in" or 2) "house" refers to the people who live in it. AT: "your family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The phrase "burn up" means to burn something completely. If a person is "burnt up," it means that person is burned to death. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Did you invite us here in order to make us poor
tn.text: They ask her this question to accuse her of inviting them there to make them poor.  This question can be written as a statement. AT: "You have brought us here to make us poor!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
They would become poor if they had to buy him new clothes if they could not solve the riddle. AT: "to make us poor by forcing us to buy him new clothes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: All you do is hate me! You do not love me
tn.text: Samson's wife basically said the same thing twice for emphasis. AT: "You do not really love me at all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
a game in which the players must discover the answer to a difficult question
This is an idiom used to get someones attention. Here "look" means to "listen." AT: "Listen to me" or "Pay attention to what I am about to say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: if I have not told my father or my mother, should I tell you?
tn.text: Samson was rebuking her for demanding that he tell her the answer. This question can be written as a statement. AT: "I have not even told my father or mother. I will not tell you." or "you should not demand that I tell you, since I have not even told my parents, and they are closer to me than you are." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: during the seven days that their feast lasted
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "during the seven days of their feast" or 2) "during the rest of the seven days of their feast."
"the 7th day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
Here the word "pressured" means "urged." AT: "she kept urging him to tell her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This refers to Samson's wife's relatives. This can be stated clearly. AT: "the young men" or "her relatives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"the 7th day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])

tn.ref: What is sweeter than honey? What is stronger than a lion?
tn.text: This is the answer to the riddle. It may be written as a statement instead of as questions. If necessary it could be made clear how this relates to the riddle by adding more information. AT: "Honey is sweet and a lion is strong." or "Honey is sweet and it came out of a lion." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: If you had not plowed with my heifer
tn.text: Samson compares their using his wife to get the answer to someone using another person's heifer to plow his field. AT: "If you had not used my wife" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
To plow is to use an animal to pull a blade through soil to prepare the soil for seeds.

The phrase "came on" means that Yahweh's Spirit influenced Samson. In this case, he made him very strong. AT: "made Samson very strong" or "made Samson very powerful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"killed 30 men" - (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"the men who lived there"
things taken by force, usually after a fight or battle
These were from the plunder he had taken from Ashkelon. AT: "the sets of clothing that he had taken" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"very angry"

tn.ref: went up to his father's house
tn.text: The phrase "went up" is used here because Samson was at Timnah which is lower in elevation than where his father's house is located.

tn.ref: Samson's wife was given to his best friend
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "his wife's father gave her to his best friend" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"closest friend"
